prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 31 mJy for a spectral bin of 15 km/s. To reach an SNR of 10 per bin, we request 3.1mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 10 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 150 km/s wide, we use 15 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.8" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 2.8arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 17 arcsec
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 2 mJy for a spectral bin of 72 km/s. To reach an SNR of 5 per bin, we request 0.4mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 5 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 360 km/s wide, we use 72 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.8" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 3.3arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 20 arcsec. We expect that the flux has an exponential fall outwards, so the main emission will be concentrated within 1/3 of the synthesized beam and we thus do not need a mosaic.
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 3 mJy for a spectral bin of 80 km/s. To reach an SNR of 5 per bin, we request 0.6mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 5 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 400 km/s wide, we use 80 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.5" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 2.5arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 15 arcsec
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 3 mJy for a spectral bin of 20 km/s. To reach an SNR of 5 per bin, we request 0.6mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 5 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 100 km/s wide, we use 20 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.8" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 3.3arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 20 arcsec. We expect that the flux has an exponential fall outwards, so the main emission will be concentrated within 1/3 of the synthesized beam and we thus do not need a mosaic.
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 7.2 mJy for a spectral bin of 50 km/s. To reach an SNR of 7.2, we request 1.0mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 5 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 250 km/s wide, we use 50 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.5" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 3.3arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 20 arcsec. We expect that the flux has an exponential fall outwards, so the main emission will be concentrated within 1/3 of the synthesized beam and we thus do not need a mosaic.
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 30 mJy for a spectral bin of 30 km/s. To reach an SNR of 10, we request 3.0mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 10 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 300 km/s wide, we use 30 km/s bins

The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 2.7arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 16 arcsec
The expected peak flux for the requested synthesized beam is 12 mJy for a spectral bin of 28 km/s. To reach an SNR of 10, we request 1.2mJy RMS noise.

The set-up is made to contain 3 continuum (TDM) spectral windows and one spectral-line (FDM) spectral window. Since we require 5 spectral resolution elements per FWHM of the line, and the line is 190 km/s wide, we use 28 km/s bins

One of the goals of the proposal is to resolve scales of ~70pc at the distance of this target, which implies 0.6" resolution. The Largest Scales to recover are determined from the CO distribution assuming that all the flux is within a Gaussian of 1 sigma = 2.2arsec. The 6-sigma value is therefore 13 arcsec

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(1-0) mapping observations of 7 nearby elliptical galaxies. The galaxies were selected for their proximity, and for evidence of the presence of molecular gas in their central regions. With spatial resolutions of ~0.5-1", we will be able to resolve local structures within the molecular gas at scales comparable to those of large galactic giant molecular clouds. Furthermore, we intend to carry out a detailed study of the local and large scale dynamics of any molecular gas present in these objects. The data obtained in these observations will be used to study in unprecedented detail the mechanisms of star formation/inhibition in elliptical galaxies, origin of the molecular gas in these objects, and try to detect organized local molecular structures in them (GMCs, spiral arms, wisps, etc). These properties will be compared with those of lenticulars and spirals in the literature. ALMA Cycle 3 is ideally suited for these observations, providing both the required sensitivity and high-quality imaging for this project.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
